stk.molecular.topologies.cage.base module¶

class stk.molecular.topologies.cage.base.CageTopology(A_alignments=None, B_alignments=None, edge_alignments=None, bb_positions=None)¶

Bases: stk.molecular.topologies.base.Topology

An abstract base class for cage topologies.

A_alignments¶

The length of this list must be equal to the number of building blocks in the cage. When cages are built one of the fgs of each building block is aligned with an edge during placement. The int is the id of the aligned functional group.

If None then the functional group with id of 0 is always aligned.

For example,

A_alignments = [0, 2, 1, 2]

In this case there must be 4 building blocks in the cage. The the first building block has its first (id = 0) fg aligned. The 2nd building block has the 3rd fg (id = 2) aligned. The 3rd building block has the 2nd fg (id = 1) aligned. The 4th building block has the 3rd fg (id = 2) aligned.

Type:list of int
B_alignments¶

The length of this list should be equal to the number of linkers in the cage. The linkers of a cage can have either 2 functional groups or 3 or more, depending on the topology.

When the linkers have 2 functional groups, the list should hold either 1 or -1. The value indicates that the linker is aligned parallel or antiparallel with the edge its placed on. For example, in a tetrahedral topology,

B_alignments = [-1, 1, 1, -1, 1, -1]

It indicates that the first linker is aligned anti parallel and the second is aligned in parallel, and so on.

If the linkers have 3 or more functional groups, the values in B_alignments have the same role as A_alignments. The only difference is that by default the second fg is aligned, rather than the first.

Type:list of int
edge_alignments¶

The length of the list is equal to the number of building blocks in the cage. Each element is an int which holds the id of an edge. For example,

edge_alignments = [1, 2, 3, 4]

then the first building block is aligned with the edge with Vertex.id_ of 1, the second building block is aligned with the edge with Vertex.id_ 2 and so on. For this to work, the edges must have their Vertex.id_ attributes defined.

Type:list of int
bb_positions¶

A dict of the form

bb_positions = {
    bb1: [0, 1, 3],
    bb2: [2]
    bb3: [0, 4, 5],
    bb4: [1, 2, 3]
}

where bb1 and bb2 are the StructUnit3 objects used to initialize the cage and bb3, bb4 are the StructUnit3 objects used to initialize a cage:

cage = Cage([bb1, bb2, bb3, bb4],
            stk.FourPlusSix(bb_positions=bb_positions))

This means bb1 sits on the vertices 0, 1, and 3, bb2 sits on vertex 2 of the cage, while bb3 sits on the edges 0, 4 and 5 and bb4 sits on the edges 1, 2 and 3. The vertices and edges can be found in class attributes positions_A and positions_B of each cage topology. Vertex 0 therefore refers to the vertex with index 0 in positions_A and so on.

If bb_positions=None then building blocks are placed on edges and vertices at random.

It is also possible to specify the building blocks via their index, for example:

bb_positions = {
    0: [0, 1, 3],
    1: [2]
    2: [0, 4, 5],
    3: [1, 2, 3]
}

Here bb1 was replaced by 0 because it has an index of 0 during cage construction, recall:

cage = Cage([bb1, bb2, bb3, bb4],
            stk.FourPlusSix(bb_positions=bb_positions))

equally bb2 is replaced by 1 in bb_positions because it has an index of 1 and so on.

Type:dict
_func_groups¶

Keeps track of the functional groups in the macromolecule during assembly.

Type:list of FunctionalGroup
__init__(A_alignments=None, B_alignments=None, edge_alignments=None, bb_positions=None)¶

Initialize self. See help(type(self)) for accurate signature.

_bb_maps(macro_mol)¶

Creates a maps from position to building block.

Parameters:macro_mol (MacroMolecule) – The macromolecule which needs to have its building blocks mapped to positions.
Returns:Each dict maps a position to the building block which sits on it. The position is refered to its index in positions_A or positions_B.
Return type:tuple of dict
bonded_fgs(macro_mol)¶

Joins up the separate building blocks which form the molecule.

Parameters:macro_mol (MacroMolecule) – The macromolecule being assembled.
Yields:tuple of int – The fg_ids of functional groups to be bonded.
build(macro_mol, bb_conformers=None)¶

Assembles rdkit instances of macromolecules.

This method places an rdkit molecule of the assembled macromolecule into the mol attribute of MacroMolecule. It also creates the MacroMolecule.bb_counter and MacroMolecule.bonds_made attributes.

Parameters:
  • macro_mol (MacroMolecule) – The MacroMolecule instance which needs to be built.
  • bb_conformers (list of int, optional) – The ids of the building block conformers to be used. Must be equal in length to building_blocks and orders must correspond. If None, then -1 is used for all building blocks.
Returns:

None
Return type:

NoneType
cleanup(macro_mol)¶

Performs final clean up actions on an assembled molecule.

Parameters:macro_mol (MacroMolecule) – The molecule being assembled.
Returns:None
Return type:NoneType
pair_fgs_with_positions(scale, macro_mol, vertex)¶

Matches fgs with the closest building block position.

After a building block is placed on a position, each fg which forms a bond must be paired with the location of the building block to which it bonds. This function matches fgs and positions so that each is only present in one pairing and so that the total distance of the pairings is minimized.

This updates of Vertex.fg_position_pairs attribute of vertex.

Parameters:
  • scale (float) – The amount by which the size of the topology is scaled.
  • macro_mol (MacroMolecule) – The macromolecule being buit.
  • vertex (Vertex) – The position at which all the atoms being paired are located.
Returns:

None
Return type:

NoneType
place_mols(macro_mol)¶

Places all building block molecules on correct coordinates.

The building block molecules are placed in their appropriate positions based on the topology. It does not join them.

Also updates MacroMolecule.bb_counter.

Parameters:macro_mol (MacroMolecule) – The macromolecule being built.
Returns:None
Return type:NoneType
prepare(macro_mol)¶

Performs ops between placing and reacting building blocks.

Parameters:macro_mol (MacroMolecule) – The molecule being assembled.
Returns:None
Return type:NoneType
class stk.molecular.topologies.cage.base.Edge(v1, v2, id_=None, custom_position=False)¶

Bases: stk.molecular.topologies.cage.base.Vertex

Used to represent the edges of Cage polyhedra.

This class stores information about the edges which make up a cage’s structure.

direction¶

This vector represents the orientation of the edge. It is a normalized direction vector which runs from v2 to v1, provided in the initalizer.

Type:numpy.ndarray
__init__(v1, v2, id_=None, custom_position=False)¶

Initializes an Edge instance.

Parameters:
  • v1 (Vertex) – A vertex joined to the edge.
  • v2 (Vertex) – Another vertex joined to the edge.
  • id (:class`str`, optional) – An id for the edge.
  • custom_position (bool) – See Vertex.custom_position
bonder_centroid(macro_mol, scale)¶

Calculates the centroid of the fgs on the vertex.

However if custom_position is True or macro_mol is None, then coord is returned.

Parameters:
  • macro_mol (MacroMolecule) – The macromolecule being built.
  • scale (float) – The amount by which the size of the topology is scaled.
Returns:

The centroid of the bonder atoms.
Return type:

numpy.ndarray
direction(macro_mol, scale)
edge_centroid(scale)¶

Returns the centroid of the edges connected to the vertex.

Parameters:scale (float) – The amount by which the size of the topology is scaled.
Returns:An array which holds the x, y and z positions of the centroid of the edges connected to the vertex.
Return type:numpy.ndarray
edge_coord_matrix(scale)¶

Return matrix holding coords of edges joined to the vertex.

Parameters:scale (float) – The amount by which the size of the topology is scaled.
Returns:The matrix of shape [n, 3], where n is the number of edges connected to the vertex. The row holds the x, y and z coordinates, respectively.
Return type:numpy.matrix
edge_direction_vectors(scale)¶

Yields direction vectors between edges connected to the vertex.

Parameters:scale (float) – The amount by which the size of the topology is scaled.
Yields:numpy.ndarray – A normalized direction vector running from one edge connected to the vertex to another.
edge_plane(scale)¶

Return coefficients of plane of edges connected to the vertex.

A plane is defined by the scalar plane equation:

ax + by + cz = d.

This method returns the a, b, c and d coefficients of this equation for the plane formed by the connected edges. The coefficents a, b and c describe the normal vector to the plane. The coefficent d is found by substituting these coefficients along with the x, y and z variables in the scalar equation and solving for d. The variables x, y and z are substituted by the coordinate of some point on the plane. For example, the position of one of the connected edges.

Parameters:scale (float) – The amount by which the size of the topology is scaled.
Returns:This array has the form [a, b, c, d] and represents the scalar equation of the plane formed by the connected edges.
Return type:numpy.ndarray

References

https://tinyurl.com/okpqv6

edge_plane_normal(scale)¶

Return the normal of the plane formed by the connected edges.

The normal is set such that it always points away from the origin.

Parameters:scale (float) – The amount by which the size of the topology is scaled.
Returns:A normalized vector which defines the normal pointed away from the origin.
Return type:numpy.ndarray
place_mol(scale, linker, alignment, macro_mol)¶

Places a linker molecule on the coordinates of an edge.

It also orientates the linker so that the fgs sit exactly on the edge and the bulk of the linker points away from the center of the cage.

Parameters:
  • scale (float) – The amount by which the size of the topology is scaled.
  • linker (StructUnit2) – The linker which is to be placed and orientated as described in the docstring.
  • alignment (int) – 1 for parallel alignment with direction and -1 for anti-parallel alignment with direction.
  • macro_mol (MacroMolecule) – The macromolecule being constructed.
Returns:

The rdkit instance holding the linker molecule with the coordinates placed on the edge and orientation set as described in the docstring.
Return type:

rdkit.Mol
classmethod vertex_init(*vertices)¶

Intializes the Vertex from other vertices.

This initalizer automatically calculates the position of the vertex from the positions of the vertices provided to the initializer. Its position is set to the centroid of the provided vertices.

The connected attributes of all the involved vertices are also updated.

Parameters:vertices (tuple of Vertex) – Holds Vertex objects used for initialization.
Returns:The initialized vertex.
Return type:Vertex
class stk.molecular.topologies.cage.base.NoLinkerCageTopology(alignments=None, bb_positions=None)¶

Bases: stk.molecular.topologies.cage.base.CageTopology

Abstract base class for cage topologies without linkers.

This means that all building blocks have the same number of functional groups.

alignments¶

See CageTopology.A_alignments

class stk.molecular.topologies.cage.base.Vertex(x, y, z, id_=None, custom_position=True)¶

Bases: object

Used to represent the vertices of cage polyhedra.

This class stores information about the vertices which make up a cage’s structure.

coord¶

The x, y and z coordinates of the vertex, in that order.

Type:numpy.ndarray
connected¶

The Edge or Vertex instances which represent the edges or vertices connected to this one.

Type:list of (Edge or Vertex)
fgs¶

The functional groups placed on the vertex.

Type:list of FunctionalGroup
fg_position_pairs¶

A list of the form

fg_position_pairs = [(fg1, v1), (fg2, v2)]

Where v1 and v2 are Vertex instances and fg1 and fg2 are FunctionalGroup instances.

Each fg which is paired to a neighboring vertex or edge first. Only after this is the fg-fg pairing performed. The fg-(edge/vertex) pairing is stored here.

Type:list
distances¶

A list of the form

distances = [(15.2, fg1, fg2), (18.4, fg3, fg4), ...]

After fgs have been associated with vertices to which they join, the idividual fgs are paired up. To do this the distance between every fg on the paired vertex and the fg which is paired to the vertex is found. This information is stored here the first element of each tuple the distance, and the second and third elements represent are FunctionalGroup instances.

Type:list
id¶

An id to identify the vertex. Used by CageTopology.place_mols().

Type:object, optional
custom_position¶

A flag to inidcate if the position of coord was derived from connected vertices or set manually. If the position is derived from the vertices then the position of the building block being placed is derived from the bonder atoms in the connected vertices.

Type:bool
__init__(x, y, z, id_=None, custom_position=True)¶

Initializes a Vertex.

Parameters:
  • x (int or float) – The x coordinate.
  • y (int or float) – The y coordinate
  • z (int or float) – The z coordinate
  • id (object, optional) – An id to identify the vertex.
  • custom_position (bool, optional) – See custom_position.
bonder_centroid(macro_mol, scale)¶

Calculates the centroid of the fgs on the vertex.

However if custom_position is True or macro_mol is None, then coord is returned.

Parameters:
  • macro_mol (MacroMolecule) – The macromolecule being built.
  • scale (float) – The amount by which the size of the topology is scaled.
Returns:

The centroid of the bonder atoms.
Return type:

numpy.ndarray

edge_plane(scale)¶

Return coefficients of plane of edges connected to the vertex.

A plane is defined by the scalar plane equation:

ax + by + cz = d.

This method returns the a, b, c and d coefficients of this equation for the plane formed by the connected edges. The coefficents a, b and c describe the normal vector to the plane. The coefficent d is found by substituting these coefficients along with the x, y and z variables in the scalar equation and solving for d. The variables x, y and z are substituted by the coordinate of some point on the plane. For example, the position of one of the connected edges.

Parameters:scale (float) – The amount by which the size of the topology is scaled.
Returns:This array has the form [a, b, c, d] and represents the scalar equation of the plane formed by the connected edges.
Return type:numpy.ndarray

References

https://tinyurl.com/okpqv6

edge_plane_normal(scale)¶

Return the normal of the plane formed by the connected edges.

The normal is set such that it always points away from the origin.

Parameters:scale (float) – The amount by which the size of the topology is scaled.
Returns:A normalized vector which defines the normal pointed away from the origin.
Return type:numpy.ndarray
place_mol(scale, building_block, aligner=0, aligner_edge=0, macro_mol=None)¶

Place a StructUnit3 building block on the vertex.

The orientation of the building block is aligned with 2 parameters. Firstly, the normal of the plane of fgs of the building block is aligned with the normal of the plane formed by the edges connected to the vertex. Because the normal of the plane of fgs always points in the direction of the building block’s centroid, this alignment causes the bulk of the building block molecule to point away from the center of the cage.

Secondly, the building block is rotated so that a fg is aligned perfectly with an edge. This reduces the rms distance between the edges and fgs to some extent, probably.

Parameters:
  • scale (float) – The amount by which the size of the topology is scaled.
  • building_block (StructUnit3) – The building block molecule to be placed on a vertex.
  • aligner (int, optional) – The fg_id of the aligned fg.
  • aligner_edge (int, optional) – The index of an edge in connected. It is the edge with which aligner is aligned.
  • macro_mol (MacroMolecule, optional) – The macromolecule being built. Used for vertex only cage topologies where the position of some of the vertices is derived from the positions of the fgs on connected vertices.
Returns:

The rdkit instance holding the building block molecule with the coordinates placed on the vertex and orientation set as described in the docstring.
Return type:

rdkit.Mol
classmethod vertex_init(*vertices)¶

Intializes the Vertex from other vertices.

This initalizer automatically calculates the position of the vertex from the positions of the vertices provided to the initializer. Its position is set to the centroid of the provided vertices.

The connected attributes of all the involved vertices are also updated.

Parameters:vertices (tuple of Vertex) – Holds Vertex objects used for initialization.
Returns:The initialized vertex.
Return type:Vertex
